Thanks for your advice, Peter. Could you explain how GA works in 
NEAT? The=
re is elitism in the program, I thought it would ensure the 
convergence of=
 the algorithm, but it seems there are other mechanisms 
that govern the pr=
ocess. Since the elites are preserved, why does the 
process still get stuc=
k? And the networks have barely grown too 
large, with an average number of=
 hidden nodes less than 10 for 
several hundred generations. I think the al=
gorithm optimizes too 
slowly, is there some method to change this? I am un=
der MATLAB_NEAT, 
and unfamiliar with programming languages other than C an=
d java.

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "petar_chervenski" 
<petar_chervenski=
@...> wrote:
>
> Check your speciation parameters and the importance factor=
s for 
> speciation. Sometimes there are too many species, sometimes there =

are 
> too few. The dropoff age is important, too. The overall slow down 
=
is 
> because the networks grow in size and the simpler species reach 
thei=
r 
> dropoff age and get killed of by NEAT. This is the explanation why 
> =
the fitness drops, too. You can have an absolute elitism where the 
> best =
species never get killed, no matter how old it is. It seems 
that 
> a fitn=
ess plateau is being reached and NEAT finds it difficult to 
> optimize in =
a high-dimentional space, the smaller species already 
> being dead and the=
 more complex are left.
> A possible thing to try is to implement a pruning=
 mechanism. The 
> phased pruning techniqe by Colin Green (found in SharpNE=
AT) is the 
> one I recommend. This will improve the speed as well as the q=
uality 
> of the overall search. With phased pruning, the lower dimentional=
 
> space is searched better. This helps finding the best starting 
point 
=
> for future generations. 
> 
> Peter
